This is an Atom formatted XML site feed. It is intended to be viewed in a Newsreader. Alternatively you can view the HTML archives at https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk/cgi-bin/webadmin?A0=ADM-HEA.
LISTSERV Web Interface 2.4.1 2015-03-09T11:36:27Z Amy Robinson 2015-03-09T11:37:32+00:00 2015-03-09T11:37:32+00:00 Planes, trains and automobiles: mechanical engineering archives now online https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ADM-HEA;5385a83d.1503 Over 1700 images from the archives and historic book collection of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers (IMechE) are now available online via VADS at: http://www.vads.ac.uk/collections/IMECHE<br><br>The archive charts the history of the Institution and of mechanical engineering, covering topics from railways to manufacturing, spanning the late 1800's to the late 1900's. Zombies! Zombies! An Interdisciplinary Symposium | 28 February 2015 https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ADM-HEA;e90755e9.1502 Zombies! Zombies! Zombies! An Interdisciplinary Symposium<br>Saturday 28th February 2015 | University of Brighton<br><br>9.30am-4pm, Boardroom M2, Grand Parade Building, University of Brighton<br><br>Confirmed Speakers Include:<br>Naomi Alderman (author of Disobedience, The Liars Gospel and Zombies, Run!)<br>Stacey Abbott (University of Roehampton)<br>Diane Carr (UCL, Institute of Education)<br><br>Zombies are emerging everywhere in popular culture. In comic books and graphic novels, on the small and silver screen, in videogames and board games. The undead have recently risen as a returning figure in contemporary fiction, contaminating works of classic literature, which are themselves reimagined as sequential art and fan fiction. Following [...] Ken Friedman 2015-02-02T19:28:11+01:00 2015-02-02T19:28:11+01:00 Updated Research and Writing Resources https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ADM-HEA;79c65c27.1502 Dear Colleagues,<br><br>This week, I posted updated versions of several papers on research, research skills, doctoral supervision, research writing, and publishing to my Academia page.<br><br>https://swinburne.academia.edu/KenFriedman<br><br>These papers contain corrections and improvements, along with updated information.<br><br>Please feel free to use these in teaching, research training, and doctoral supervision. You are also free to use them in digital resource collections. It is a competition that encourages new approaches to the film medium. [...] Ken Friedman 2014-12-13T13:07:55+08:00 2014-12-13T13:07:55+08:00 CfP: 'Environmental Histories of Design' - workshop at RCC in Munich, 19 June 2015 https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ADM-HEA;e85a633e.1412 Call for Papers: 'Environmental Histories of Design' - a workshop at Rachel Carson Center for Environment and Society in Munich, 19 June 2015.<br><br>Design and designers hold an ambiguous place in contemporary environmental discourse. They can easily be blamed for causing environmental problems, but also have the competences required for solving those problems. Despite this long-standing centrality of design to environmental discourse, and vice versa, deep and systematic \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdenvironmental histories of design\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd are few and far between. While environmental historians have increasingly explored technology and material culture as active agents in discourses of environmental change, design is seldom explicitly addressed. Collaboratively authored by (in alphabetical order): Ken Friedman, Tongji University College of Design and Innovation and Swinburne University Centre for Design Innovation; Yongqi Lou, Tongji; Don Norman, University of California, San Diego, Design Lab; Pieter Jan Stappers, Delft University of Technology, Faculty of Industrial Design Engineering; Ena Vo\ufffd\ufffdte, Delft; and Patrick Whitney, Illinois Institute of Technology, Institute of Design. marchetb 2014-12-01T10:42:34+01:00 2014-12-01T10:42:34+01:00 Ethnographic Research Project ADM-HEA Mailing List https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ADM-HEA;ce19a76b.1412 Dear all,<br><br>I am a student at the joint master program \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdDigital Curation\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd at<br>Humboldt Universiatet zu Berlin/King's College London. I am conducting a<br>small ethnographic research project related to digital environments.<br><br>I would like to ask you if you are able to answer some questions about<br>your experience with this mailing list, in order to gain a better<br>awareness and knowledge of the background of subscribers. Then if you<br>will be available, I would like to ask you questions in more depth about<br>the topic. The University of Brighton offers a unique context for the conference, as it brings long-standing traditions of visual arts practice into a dynamic relationship with critical research and scholarship. We believe this will be a productive and intellectually expansive environment in which to extend the visual methods debate within and beyond the academy. It also examines what someone needs to do to become an independent researcher \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd that is, someone who can manage his or her own research projects without a supervisor.
